Award.AwardTitle: University of the Virgin Islands: Living on Earth III: Social-Ecological Systems Workshop 2012, October 24-28, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Living on Earth III (LOE III) workshop, October 24-28, 2012, University of the Virgin Islands,addresses the need for effective integration of processes linking scientific knowledge and analytical approaches in social-ecological systems research. This workshop continues the important work of the two previous workshops (LOE I and II) organized and hosted by Alaska EPSCoR, between 2009-2011, including among others, building science and research capacity in sustainability science and coupled human-natural/socio-ecological systems (SES) science across EPSCoR jurisdictions and facilitating the formalization and functionality of a LOE-SES scientific network promotes cutting-edge and transformative science ideas. LOE III focuses on conceptualizing SES science in the context of small, yet critical ecosystems with challenging human dimensions. Specifically,the workshop emphasizes three focal themes, namely, promoting science to inform our knowledge and understanding of critical coupled human-natural system transformations; the role of social emergence in addressing vulnerability while promoting ecosystem stewardship across multiple social-ecological transformations, and; deepening scientific integration at nested multiple scales promoting sustainable and resilient outcomes. In addition to these three core themes, the LOE III workshop provides participants and participant EPSCoR jurisdictions the skills and capability to build and develop social-ecological system's activities at their home institutions, by offering a "Bringing it Home" activity development session. In this session the workshop participants create a meaningful social-ecological systems exercise for their local community, university, and/or institution.

Evaluation of the workshop will be conducted in multiple levels: continuously throughout the workshop by incorporating participant evaluations following the scientific discourse and interactive dialogue; online through a survey tool for each session and for the overall experience of the workshop, and post-workshop by EPSCoR jurisdictions where each team will be tasked to report on specific outcomes promoted or planned after the LOE III experience.

Specific outcomes from the workshop are to: (a)formalize and structure a new LOE-SES EPSCoR scientific network building upon previous informal network approaches from LOE I and II; (b) generate thematic sub-network groups with specific aims and goals (such as NSF proposal submissions incorporating cross-EPSCoR collaborations, special-issue or book proposal submissions, sections or panel proposals for conferences and scientific meetings, etc., and; (c) develop a LOE-SES network toolkit for building within-EPSCoR jurisdictional capacity especially for integrating biophysical with social/behavioral scientists for SES science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During October 23-26, 2012, the Virgin Islands Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (VI-EPSCoR) and the University of the Virgin Islands hosted on the island of St. Thomas in the U. S. Virgin Islands, the national EPSCoR Living on Earth Social-Ecological Systems workshop (LOE III). The workshop was the third event of the National Science Foundation's Living on Earth Series, following the success of the LOE I and II workshops hosted by the Alaska EPSCoR program in 2009 and 2011 respectively. Collectively, the three Living on Earth workshops have formed a strong community of scholars across many of the nation's EPSCoR States and Territories, and has strengthened and formalized effective exchanges of ideas, collaborations, research and educational approaches to social-ecological sustainability and stewardship. The LOE III workshop addressed the need for more effective and efficient integration between scientific knowledge and empirical approaches in linking human and natural dimensions of environmental change.
    The LOE III workshop hosted more than 60 participants from 20 EPSCoR jurisdictions across the country ranging from Alaska to the US Virgin Islands and from Maine to Nevada and including many other jurisdictions. The participants of the LOE III workshop represented a range of biophysical sciences expertise (e.g., environmental science, physics, mathematics, climate science, marine science), as well as social sciences expertise (e.g., geographic sciences, decision sciences, social, economic and behavioral sciences). The assembly therefore depicted a unique mix of scientific disciplines and domains of knowledge.  The scope and goals of the workshop focused on how scientists across the nation and through true trans-disciplinary investigations can work together to tackle some of our most critical and profound environmental challenges, -those of understanding how our human communities interact with their natural ecosystems, and vice versa. Furthermore, the LOE III workshop continued to foster (as was the case with LOE I and LOE II) approaches that favor shared exchanges of theory, tools and analytical methods for understanding social-ecological systems and their changes across a variety of situations and experiences ranging from our local communities, to our critical regions, to our national and global environmental challenges.
    During the LOE III workshop, the researchers engaged in participatory and interactive exercises along with active dialogue and discussion aimed on three key themes:
(a) How can we use our trans-disciplinary scientific expertise to understand social-ecological systems especially in areas where small local communities interact with critical ecological systems?
(b) How can social science help us to study, understand and enhance stewardship in ways that can promote healthy and sustainable ecosystems while reducing the vulnerability of our communities and societies to environmental changes?
(c) How can our science help us to investigate in depth the integration of all these environmental issues across space (e.g., our jurisdictions), time, and on multiple scales, from land to coastal to ocean systems?
    The LOE III workshop included a number of keynote addresses where prominent scientists shared their approaches and experiences with social-ecological systems science with the participants. As part of the LOE III workshop process, the participants were addressed by the Governor of the US Virgin Islands and the President of the University of the Virgin Islands. Both individuals stressed in their deliveries, the importance of the study of social-ecological systems in addressing some of the Territory's critical environmental challenges.
